“Mental models” is my shorthand term for the idea that the way a single human mind comprehends reality, is not reality. It is the distinction that the way we think about something is not the totality of that thing.

The saying “The map is not the territory” is the most common expression for this idea. Why is it important to note this distinction? To avoid forgetting the distinction, and ending up thinking that our perception of reality is actually reality. The negative consequence of letting that replacement happen is we lose touch with reality, and as conditions and circumstances change, we fail to adjust are thinking and actions to our context.

Why can’t we know the totality of a thing or reality itself?
  • poor sensory ability
  • cognition is continuously filling in the gaps
  • We can only hold so many factors in our head
  • Verification though communication and language is not enough to overcome these challenges
Does reality exist then?

I think there is a very strong case for reality existing. Without diving off the metaphysical or spiritual deep-ends

What does it look like?
  • Acknowledging that even strongly held concepts about the world are inaccurate in some way.
  • Acknowledging that any model of the world is going to be some sort of simplification of what is going on.
  • While these factors mean that we accept that all models are wrong, we can also determine that some models are more ‘useful’ than others.
